title_en: Delays, flight cancellations and thousands of passengers affected by the coercive measure promoted by the Brotherhood: trains run at 30 kilometers per hour
summary_en:
The Brotherhood trade union is promoting a forceful measure due to the lack of a wage agreement with the railway companies.
Metro trains run at a speed of no more than 30 kilometers per hour, causing serious complications and doubling travel time.
The guild has confirmed that the activity will be completely stopped next Tuesday, June 4.
The hearings organized by the Ministry of Labor, Employment and Social Security did not yield positive results.
The railway companies proposed to increase the payment for April by 2% and then by the remaining 7%, which will be applied in calculations for May.
The payment plan stipulated that both percentages would be paid together with the June holdings.
A forceful measure is the application of speed limits on trains intended for the transportation of passengers and cargo.
Due to the lack of responses, the union expanded the claim, announcing a complete cessation of activities next Tuesday, June 4.

title_en: Border Force officers at Heathrow will strike for three days in a row
summary_en:
More than 500 PCS union members at Heathrow are holding a three-day strike over disagreements over employee lists.
The union said that more than 250 employees could lose their jobs or be transferred to another job against their will.
Those who stay will have longer shifts, inflexible shift rules, lack of clarity in vacation arrangements, and the inability to circumvent nursing responsibilities.
A petition was launched in support of the workers.
The PCS General Secretary calls on all trade unionists and the public to support the petition and ask the leadership of the border troops to abandon the list.
The strikes will be followed by three weeks of strikes by workers, including a ban on overtime work.
Last year, the government passed a controversial new law aimed at ensuring a minimum level of service during strikes.

title_en: The British Columbia Nurses Union holds rallies for the ratio of nurses to patients
summary_en:
Hundreds of nurses in British Columbia are protesting unsafe working conditions.
The survey revealed a large number of incidents of violence and the use of illegal drugs at work.
The British Columbia Nurses Union has negotiated with the government on a minimum nurse-to-patient ratio.
More than 35% of nurses say they want to leave the profession, and many are already planning to do so.
Nurses are demanding improvements in other working conditions that can undermine the ratio of nurses to patients.
About 40% of the British Columbia nursing population is exposed to guns and illegal drugs.
The Minister of Health of British Columbia announced work to improve the safety conditions for nurses.

title_en: Port Talbot Steelworkers Union announces date of industrial action
summary_en:
The steelworkers' unions in Port Talbot have announced an industrial action.
Unite's action is in response to plans to close both blast furnaces, threatening thousands of jobs in South Wales.
The furnaces will be replaced with electric arc furnaces to reduce emissions and costs, but unions warn of 2,800 jobs at risk.
About 1,500 Tata steelworkers will start work on June 18 and take part in the ban on overtime work.
The unions do not rule out a strike if the demands of the members are not met and the company's plans are not changed.
Tata has "miscalculated," the unions say, and they will fight for a better future using all available tools.
A representative of Tata Steel expressed disappointment with Unite's statement and said that it would continue to analyze and consider further legal steps.

title_en: Gasoline shortages are forecast next week due to a strike by courier drivers
summary_en:
Travel chaos and gasoline shortages are expected next week due to a strike by courier drivers at the forecourts.
The strike was caused by low wages for drivers delivering goods to the forecourts.
A strike can lead to aircraft shutdowns and problems refueling at gas stations.
Shell, BP and Esso Forecourts depend on gasoline supplies from Oxalis, which can cause significant disruptions in fuel supplies.
There is a risk of an expansion of the gasoline crisis if other drivers also refuse to cross the picket line.
The dispute centers on the pay of drivers who claim they are being offered significantly lower salaries than colleagues in other parts of the country.
Unite says Oxalis drivers in Thurrock and Birmingham are being offered ¬£2 an hour more than Stanlow drivers.
Oxalis must put forward an equivalent proposal, otherwise the dispute will escalate.
